Bacterial Blight.Cause: Bacterial disease caused by Xanthomonas citri pv. malvacearum, spreading through infected seeds, rain splash, and mechanical injury. Warm, humid weather favors infection.
Bacterial Blight.Symptoms: Angular, water-soaked lesions appear on lower leaves, turning brown with yellow margins. Severe infection causes defoliation, boll rot, and reduced yield.
Precautions: Use disease-free certified seeds.
Practice crop rotation with non-host crops for 2–3 years.
Avoid overhead irrigation and high plant density.

Chemical: Seed treatment with Streptocycline (100 ppm) or copper oxychloride (0.3%).
Spray copper-based bactericides or Bordeaux mixture (1%) at early stages.
Organic: Use compost teas or neem oil spray to enhance leaf resistance.
Remove and destroy infected crop residues post-harvest.

Curl Virus.Cause: Viral disease transmitted by whiteflies (Bemisia tabaci). High temperature and dry weather conditions enhance whitefly population.
Curl Virus.Symptoms: Upward or downward curling of leaves, thickening of veins, stunted plants, and small malformed bolls.
Precautions: Grow whitefly-resistant varieties and avoid early sowing.
Monitor and control whitefly populations regularly.
Weed control and removal of alternate host plants are essential.

Chemical: Apply imidacloprid (0.05%) or thiamethoxam (0.03%) for whitefly control.
Use insect growth regulators like buprofezin for sustainable control.
Organic: Spray neem oil (3%) or neem seed kernel extract (5%) weekly.
Introduce natural predators like ladybird beetles and lacewings.

Healthy Leaf.Cause: No infection or physiological stress detected; indicates good crop management and environmental conditions.
Healthy Leaf.Symptoms: Uniform dark green leaves, no spots or deformities, proper plant height and boll formation.
Precautions: Maintain balanced irrigation and fertilizer schedule.
Monitor regularly for early pest or disease signs.
Clean tools and equipment to prevent contamination.

Organic: Maintain soil fertility using compost and vermicompost.
Apply neem oil as a preventive bio-protection spray once per month.

Herbicide Growth Damage.Cause: Chemical injury caused by herbicide drift or over-application, especially with glyphosate or 2,4-D.
Herbicide Growth Damage.Symptoms: Leaf curling, chlorosis, deformed new leaves, and stunted growth; symptoms mimic viral infections.
Precautions: Avoid herbicide drift by using shielded sprayers and low wind speed applications.
Apply herbicides only at recommended doses and timings.
Avoid tank-mixing incompatible chemicals.

Chemical: No direct chemical cure; flush with irrigation water to reduce residue effects.
Organic: Apply seaweed extract or humic acid to help plant recovery.
Enhance soil microbial activity with compost to detoxify residues.

Leaf Hopper Jassids.Cause: Caused by the sap-sucking insect Amrasca biguttula biguttula (cotton jassid). Warm and dry conditions favor its multiplication.
Leaf Hopper Jassids.Symptoms: Leaf margins turn yellow and curl downward (hopper burn); severe cases cause reddening, drying, and leaf drop.
Precautions: Grow jassid-tolerant cotton varieties.
Use yellow sticky traps to monitor and reduce pest populations.
Avoid excessive nitrogen fertilizer that promotes tender leaves.

Chemical: Spray imidacloprid (0.05%) or acetamiprid (0.004%) when pest count exceeds threshold.
Organic: Spray neem seed kernel extract (5%) or pongamia oil (2%) regularly.
Encourage natural predators like spiders and ladybird beetles.

Leaf Redding.Cause: Physiological disorder caused by phosphorus or magnesium deficiency, excess nitrogen, and pest stress (especially jassids).
Leaf Redding.Symptoms: Leaves turn reddish-purple starting from the edges, reduced photosynthesis, and premature leaf fall.
Precautions: Balance N:P:K fertilization according to soil tests.
Avoid excessive irrigation and nitrogen application.
Manage jassid and mite infestations promptly.

Chemical: Apply single superphosphate or magnesium sulfate as per deficiency symptoms.
Organic: Use compost or farmyard manure enriched with rock phosphate.
Apply foliar spray of seaweed extract or micronutrient mixture.

Leaf Variegation.Cause: Caused by irregular chlorophyll development due to genetic, nutrient, or viral factors; sometimes related to stress or environmental imbalance.
Leaf Variegation.Symptoms: Irregular light and dark green patches on leaves, usually not leading to severe yield loss unless viral in nature.
Precautions: Ensure balanced nutrition, especially zinc and iron.
Avoid stress from drought or excess fertilizer.
Use disease-free seeds to prevent viral causes.

Chemical: Apply chelated micronutrient foliar sprays (Zn, Fe, Mn) as per deficiency type.
Organic: Use vermicompost and organic mulches to improve nutrient uptake.
Maintain proper soil moisture and avoid sudden stress.

Fusarium Wilt.Cause: Fungal disease caused by Fusarium oxysporum f. sp. vasinfectum; survives in soil and enters roots through wounds or stress points.
Fusarium Wilt.Symptoms: Wilting of lower leaves, yellowing, dark brown vascular discoloration inside stems, and plant death in severe cases.
Precautions: Use wilt-resistant cotton varieties.
Rotate with non-host crops for 3–4 years.
Avoid over-irrigation and maintain soil drainage.

Chemical: Soil drenching with carbendazim (0.1%) or thiophanate-methyl before planting.
Treat seeds with Trichoderma formulation before sowing.
Organic: Apply Trichoderma-enriched compost in planting furrows.
Maintain soil health with organic matter and biofertilizers.
